elements.name: Mutual Pledge Card
elements.problem_it_solves: Booking feels like a one-way consumer transaction rather than two people choosing each other, producing weak commitments that lead to cancellations and distrust.
elements.why_this_is_a_signature: No platform in the shared-housing category creates a visible moment where both host and guest make active, written pledges to each other ‚Äî users would say 'I've never had a platform make me feel like my host actually chose me, and I chose them back.'
elements.description: A split-screen commitment card shown at the acceptance stage of the proposal flow. The left half shows the host's pledge (welcome message, what they commit to providing, their expectations), and the right half shows the guest's pledge (introduction, what they commit to respecting, their stay purpose). Both sides fill in progressively as each party contributes, and a central 'handshake' visual locks when both pledges are complete. The card becomes a permanent artifact visible to both parties throughout the lease.

visual_spec.layout: CSS Grid ‚Äî two-column on desktop (1fr 1fr), single-column stacked on mobile, with a central divider/connector element
visual_spec.background: var(--bg-white) #ffffff for the card surface, with var(--bg-off-white) rgb(252,250,255) behind each pledge section
visual_spec.border: 1px solid var(--border-color) #e5e7eb, upgrading to 2px solid var(--secondary-purple) rgb(109,49,194) when both pledges are complete
visual_spec.color_usage: Primary purple for headings and the handshake icon. Secondary purple for pledge labels and the completion border. Off-white backgrounds for each pledge section to create visual separation. Accent purple for status badges showing pledge completion.

interaction_spec.default_state: Card appears with the host's pledge section filled (from their counter-proposal) and the guest's section empty with a gentle prompt. A dashed connector line between the two halves indicates the pledge is incomplete.
interaction_spec.hover: Each pledge section lifts slightly (translateY -2px) with var(--shadow-purple-md) on hover, inviting interaction.
interaction_spec.click: Clicking the guest's pledge section opens an inline text area with guided prompts: 'Tell your host about yourself' and 'What are you looking forward to about this stay?' The submit button reads 'Make Your Pledge.'
interaction_spec.animation: When both pledges are complete, the central connector animates from a dashed line to a solid handshake icon with a subtle scale-up (1.0 to 1.1 over 0.3s) and a brief purple glow (box-shadow pulse). The border transitions from gray to purple over 0.4s.
interaction_spec.responsive: On mobile (<600px), the card stacks vertically: host pledge on top, connector in the middle as a horizontal line with the handshake icon, guest pledge below. Touch targets are 48px minimum.

copy_spec.secondary_text: Great arrangements start with both people choosing each other. This is your shared agreement ‚Äî a handshake, not a checkout.
do: Use warm, personal language ‚Äî 'your host Sarah' not 'the host'
Frame pledges as voluntary acts of care, not contractual obligations
Echo the specific stay details (dates, neighborhood) to make the pledge feel concrete
dont: Never use legal language ‚Äî no 'hereby', 'agree to terms', 'binding'
Never make the pledge feel like a form ‚Äî no required fields, checkboxes, or compliance language
Never display one pledge without acknowledging the other is coming ‚Äî avoid asymmetry

before_after.before: Airbnb Instant Book: Guest clicks 'Confirm and Pay.' Host gets a notification. Neither person has made a visible, personal commitment to the other. The arrangement starts as a transaction between strangers.

elements.name: People-Like-You Review Filter
elements.problem_it_solves: Reviews are an undifferentiated mass ‚Äî a 4.9 from 200 people tells you nothing about whether people in YOUR situation had a good experience, leaving the most persuasive form of social proof (similarity-matched) completely untapped.
elements.why_this_is_a_signature: No platform in the category lets you filter reviews by stay type, purpose, or guest profile ‚Äî users would say 'I've never seen a platform show me reviews from people who are actually like me.'
elements.description: A review section enhancement for the listing page that adds horizontally scrollable filter chips above the reviews. Chips represent stay-context categories: 'Remote Workers,' 'Traveling Nurses,' 'Relocating,' '4+ Week Stays,' 'Solo Guests.' Selecting a chip filters reviews to show only those from matching guests, with a summary stat: 'Remote workers rate this space 4.8 ‚Äî workspace quality highlighted in 12 of 15 reviews.' When no filter is active, the full aggregate view shows. A small 'people like you' badge auto-suggests a filter based on the guest's profile.

visual_spec.layout: Flexbox column ‚Äî filter chip row (horizontal scroll, overflow-x: auto), summary stat bar, then filtered review cards in a vertical stack
visual_spec.background: var(--bg-white) #ffffff for the review section, var(--bg-off-white) rgb(252,250,255) for the filter chip bar background
visual_spec.border: 1px solid var(--border-color) #e5e7eb around the entire review section
visual_spec.border_radius: var(--rounded-xl) 12px for the section container, var(--rounded-pill) 20px for filter chips

spacing.gap: var(--gap-lg) 1rem between sections, var(--gap-sm) 0.5rem between chips

visual_spec.color_usage: Secondary purple for selected filter chips (filled background, white text). Unselected chips use off-white background with text-gray. The auto-suggested 'people like you' chip uses accent-purple background at 10% opacity with accent-purple text and a subtle sparkle icon.

interaction_spec.default_state: All reviews shown with aggregate stats. If the guest has a profile, one chip is auto-suggested with a gentle highlight and 'Suggested for you' micro-label. Filter chips are horizontally scrollable.
interaction_spec.hover: Unselected chips elevate slightly (translateY -1px) and gain a purple-tinted shadow. Review cards gain shadow-md on hover.
interaction_spec.click: Clicking a chip filters reviews instantly with a subtle fade transition (opacity 0 to 1 over 0.2s). The summary stat bar updates to show segment-specific data. Clicking the active chip deselects it, returning to aggregate view.
interaction_spec.animation: Filter transition uses opacity fade (0.2s) for outgoing reviews, then fade-in for matching reviews. The summary stat counter animates numerically (counting up) over 0.3s. The auto-suggested chip has a subtle background pulse on first view.
interaction_spec.responsive: On mobile, the chip row becomes a horizontally scrollable strip with scroll-snap. Review cards stack full-width. The summary stat bar becomes a compact single-line beneath the chips.

copy_spec.primary_text: What guests like you are saying
copy_spec.secondary_text: Filter reviews by stay type to see what matters most to people in your situation.
do: Use natural category names that match how guests describe themselves ‚Äî 'Remote Workers' not 'Category: Professional/Remote'
Show honest sample sizes ‚Äî '3 reviews from remote workers' not hidden when small
Frame the filter as the guest's choice ‚Äî 'Show me reviews from...' not algorithmic curation
dont: Never filter by demographics (age, gender, race) ‚Äî filter by situation and purpose only
Never hide the aggregate view ‚Äî it's the hook, similarity is the closer
Never manufacture similarity when data is thin ‚Äî say '2 reviews from remote workers' honestly

elements.name: Pre-Arrival Conversation Guide
elements.problem_it_solves: The messaging interface is a blank pipe ‚Äî neither host nor guest knows what to say, when to say it, or whether communication is even expected, causing pluralistic ignorance that suppresses the trust-building micro-commitments that predict stay satisfaction.
elements.why_this_is_a_signature: No platform in the category treats communication as a designed experience with structured prompts and social proof about what other guests typically ask ‚Äî users would say 'This is the first platform where I felt prepared and connected to my host before I even arrived.'
elements.description: A guided conversation module that appears in the messaging thread between acceptance and move-in. It presents 3-4 suggested conversation topics as expandable cards: 'Arrival Details,' 'Workspace Setup,' 'House Rhythm,' and 'Neighborhood Tips.' Each card includes a pre-written message template the guest can customize and send. A subtle social proof line reads 'Most guests discuss these topics before arriving.' As each topic is covered, it checks off with a satisfying micro-animation. The guide is suggestive, not mandatory ‚Äî it can be collapsed at any time.

visual_spec.layout: Flexbox column within the messaging thread ‚Äî conversation guide sits as a pinned card at the top of the chat, with topic cards stacked vertically inside
visual_spec.background: var(--bg-off-white) rgb(252,250,255) for the guide container, var(--bg-white) #ffffff for individual topic cards
visual_spec.border: 1px solid rgba(140, 104, 238, 0.2) for the guide container, 1px solid var(--border-color) for topic cards
visual_spec.border_radius: var(--rounded-xl) 12px for the guide container, var(--rounded-lg) 8px for topic cards

spacing.padding: var(--spacing-xl) 20px inside guide container, var(--spacing-lg) 16px inside topic cards

visual_spec.color_usage: Off-white background creates a distinct zone within the messaging thread. Secondary purple for the progress indicator and completed check icons. Accent purple at 10% for the social proof nudge background. Primary purple for headings.

interaction_spec.default_state: Guide appears as a compact card with the heading 'Prepare for your stay' and a progress indicator (0 of 4 topics). The social proof nudge is visible: 'Most guests discuss these before arriving.' Topics are listed as collapsed rows showing title and a chevron.
interaction_spec.hover: Topic cards gain subtle shadow and the chevron rotates slightly to suggest expandability.
interaction_spec.click: Clicking a topic expands it to reveal: (1) why this topic matters, (2) a pre-filled message template the guest can edit, and (3) a 'Send to host' button. Clicking 'Send' sends the message in the chat thread and marks the topic as complete.
interaction_spec.animation: Topic expansion uses height auto-transition (0.3s ease). Completion triggers a check icon that draws itself (SVG stroke-dashoffset animation over 0.4s) and the progress indicator increments with a smooth fill. When all 4 are complete, the guide collapses to a single 'You're all set!' line with a confetti-like purple sparkle.
interaction_spec.responsive: On mobile, the guide takes full width of the chat view. Topic cards expand in-place. The send button is sticky at the bottom of the expanded card for easy thumb access.

copy_spec.secondary_text: Most guests cover these topics before arriving. It takes about 5 minutes and makes your first day smoother.
do: Frame topics as helpful suggestions, not requirements ‚Äî 'Most guests ask about...' not 'You must discuss...'
Pre-fill messages with warm, natural language the guest can customize ‚Äî not corporate templates
Use the host's first name in every CTA ‚Äî 'Send to Sarah' not 'Send message'
dont: Never make the guide feel mandatory ‚Äî it should collapse easily with no guilt
Never send messages automatically ‚Äî the guest must actively choose to send
Never show more than 4 topics ‚Äî constraint prevents overwhelm and maintains the '5 minutes' promise

before_after.before: Airbnb after booking: A blank chat window. Neither host nor guest knows if they should message, what to say, or when. Most pairs exchange zero messages before arrival. Tammy: 'Airbnb just kind of leaves you to your own devices.'
before_after.after: Split Lease after acceptance: A guided conversation appears with 4 natural topics, pre-filled message templates, and social proof that 'most guests discuss these before arriving.' Trust builds through voluntary micro-commitments, not silence.

elements.name: Post-Review Forward Commitment Bridge
elements.problem_it_solves: The post-review moment ‚Äî when the guest has just publicly committed to a positive narrative ‚Äî is the peak of psychological consistency pressure, but every platform treats it as a dead end instead of a bridge to the next commitment.
elements.why_this_is_a_signature: No platform in the category leverages the emotional peak after a positive review to secure a forward commitment ‚Äî users would say 'I just said this was incredible and the platform immediately helped me act on that feeling, rather than letting it fade into a generic thank-you screen.'
elements.description: A card that appears immediately after the guest submits a positive review (4+ stars). Instead of a generic 'Thanks for your review,' it reflects the guest's own words back to them and offers three forward-commitment paths: (1) Save this host for next time, (2) See this host's upcoming availability, (3) Share your experience to help someone like you find this space. It also surfaces the guest's emerging identity: 'You've now stayed with 3 hosts across 2 cities on Split Lease.' The card is warm, personal, and leverages the peak moment.

visual_spec.layout: Flexbox column ‚Äî quote section at top, three action buttons in a row, identity line at bottom
visual_spec.background: Gradient from var(--primary-purple) #31135D to rgba(109, 49, 194, 0.9) at 135deg for the header/quote section, var(--bg-white) #ffffff for the action area
visual_spec.border: none ‚Äî the gradient header creates the visual boundary. Subtle shadow-purple-lg on the overall card

typography.heading: Inter, 20px (--text-xl), 700 weight, white (on gradient background)
typography.body: DM Sans, 14px (--text-base), 400 weight, rgba(255,255,255,0.85) for the quote, var(--text-description) for actions
typography.accent: Inter, 13px (--text-sm-md), 600 weight, var(--secondary-purple) for the identity line

spacing.padding: var(--spacing-2xl) 24px in the gradient header, var(--spacing-xl) 20px in the action area

visual_spec.color_usage: Primary-to-secondary purple gradient creates a premium, celebratory feel for the header. White text on gradient for the review quote. Secondary purple for action button outlines and the identity badge. Off-white background for the action area.

interaction_spec.default_state: Card appears with a gentle entrance animation (fade + translateY from 12px, over 0.4s). The guest's review quote is displayed in the gradient header. Three action buttons are equally sized below. The identity line shows at the very bottom.
interaction_spec.hover: Action buttons gain shadow-purple-sm and a subtle scale (1.02) on hover. The secondary CTA (share) shows a tooltip: 'Help other remote workers find great spaces.'
interaction_spec.click: Save Host: Adds to favorites with a brief confirmation animation (heart icon fill). See Availability: Opens a mini-calendar overlay showing the host's open dates. Share: Generates a shareable link or opens the native share sheet on mobile.
interaction_spec.animation: Card entrance: 0.4s ease-out fade + translateY. The review quote text appears word-by-word over 0.6s for emotional impact. The identity line fades in last (0.5s delay) as a gentle reveal. Action buttons stagger their entrance (100ms each).
interaction_spec.responsive: On mobile, action buttons stack vertically instead of in a row. The gradient header takes slightly more vertical space. The identity line remains at the bottom.

copy_spec.secondary_text: "Perfect workspace, quiet neighborhood, and Sarah was incredibly responsive. My best remote-work stay yet."
micro_copy: Help someone like you find this
You've stayed with 3 hosts across 2 cities
do: Quote the guest's own words ‚Äî their review IS the most powerful persuasion at this moment
Use the host's first name to maintain the personal relationship frame
Frame the identity line as narrative ('You've stayed with...') not gamification ('You've earned...')
dont: Never show this card after a negative review ‚Äî it should only appear for 4+ stars
Never make the forward commitment feel like a sales pitch ‚Äî the tone is celebratory, not transactional
Never use generic 'Thank you for your feedback' language ‚Äî the review is a relationship statement, not feedback

before_after.after: Split Lease after review submission: Your own words are reflected back to you on a beautiful card. Three natural next steps leverage your peak enthusiasm. And a gentle identity line reminds you that you're building a story on this platform.

elements.name: Stay Purpose Selector
elements.problem_it_solves: Guests arrive at search as anonymous browsers with unspoken, uncommitted preferences ‚Äî the platform never asks who they are or what they need, leaving the most powerful commitment device (visible preference declaration) completely unused.
elements.why_this_is_a_signature: No platform in the category asks you to declare what matters before showing listings ‚Äî users would say 'This platform actually knows what I care about and shows me results through my own lens.'
elements.description: A lightweight preference declaration step that appears at the top of the search experience. Three large, illustrated tap targets ask: 'What brings you to Split Lease?' with options like 'Working remotely,' 'Traveling for work,' 'Relocating.' Selecting one triggers a follow-up: 'What matters most?' with 2-3 quick-pick priority chips (e.g., 'Quiet workspace,' 'Close to transit,' 'Budget-friendly'). The selections persist as a visible bar above search results: 'Remote Worker ¬∑ Workspace matters most.' This bar creates the commitment anchor that Cialdini predicts will drive decisive action.

visual_spec.layout: Flexbox ‚Äî purpose options in a 3-column grid on desktop, single-column on mobile. Priority chips as horizontal flex-wrap. Persistent preference bar as a fixed-top strip above results
visual_spec.background: var(--bg-white) #ffffff for the selector card, var(--bg-off-white) rgb(252,250,255) for selected states, primary-purple gradient for the persistent preference bar
visual_spec.border: 1.5px solid var(--border-color) for unselected options, 2px solid var(--secondary-purple) for selected
visual_spec.border_radius: var(--rounded-xl) 12px for purpose cards, var(--rounded-pill) 20px for priority chips, var(--rounded-lg) 8px for the persistent bar

typography.heading: Inter, 20px (--text-xl), 700 weight, var(--primary-purple) #31135D
typography.accent: Inter, 13px (--text-sm-md), 600 weight, white (on gradient persistent bar)

spacing.padding: var(--spacing-2xl) 24px for the selector container, var(--spacing-lg) 16px inside purpose cards
spacing.gap: var(--gap-lg) 1rem between purpose cards, var(--gap-sm) 0.5rem between priority chips

visual_spec.color_usage: Secondary purple for selected state borders and checkmarks. Accent purple at low opacity for selected card backgrounds. Primary-to-secondary gradient for the persistent preference bar, creating visual consistency with the brand. White text on the gradient bar for high readability.

interaction_spec.default_state: The selector appears as a welcoming card with the heading 'What brings you here?' and three purpose options with simple illustrations. No selection is pre-made.
interaction_spec.hover: Purpose cards gain shadow-purple-sm and a subtle purple border tint on hover. Priority chips gain background fill on hover.
interaction_spec.click: Selecting a purpose: card fills with off-white background, border turns secondary-purple, and a check icon appears. The priority chips section slides in below (0.3s ease). Selecting priorities: chips toggle on/off with fill/outline states. A 'See spaces' button appears when at least one priority is selected.
interaction_spec.animation: Purpose selection triggers a brief scale pulse (1.02 over 0.15s). Priority section slides in from height 0 with eased expansion (0.3s). The persistent bar slides down from the top (0.3s ease-out) once selections are confirmed. Purpose cards stagger their entrance (80ms each).
interaction_spec.responsive: On mobile, purpose cards stack vertically as wide tap targets. Priority chips wrap naturally. The persistent bar becomes a compact strip: 'Remote Worker ¬∑ Workspace' with a tap to edit.

copy_spec.primary_text: What brings you to Split Lease?
copy_spec.secondary_text: Tell us about your stay and we'll show you spaces that match ‚Äî plus reviews from people in your situation.
do: Keep purpose options to 3-4 maximum ‚Äî too many choices creates the paralysis we're trying to solve
Frame this as 'help us help you' not 'we need your data' ‚Äî the tone is personal, not institutional
Reflect preferences back immediately and prominently ‚Äî the commitment only works if the user SEES it echoed
dont: Never make this a long form or survey ‚Äî it should take under 10 seconds total
Never lock users into their selections ‚Äî an 'Edit' option must always be visible
Never show this as a blocker ‚Äî it should be skippable with 'Browse all spaces' below

before_after.before: Airbnb homepage: A search bar. No identity question, no preference declaration, no micro-commitment. The guest browses as an anonymous consumer. Steven Mariscal does mental math converting $1200/month to nightly rates because no platform captures and reflects his priorities.

elements.name: Commitment Reassurance Badge
elements.problem_it_solves: At the peak commitment moment ‚Äî when the guest is about to submit a proposal ‚Äî there is zero social proof to reassure them, creating a 'checkout desert' where doubt is highest and psychological support is absent.
elements.why_this_is_a_signature: No platform in the category provides social proof at the commitment moment ‚Äî users would feel a genuine wave of reassurance at the exact moment they're most nervous about committing real money to a shared living arrangement.
elements.description: A compact reassurance badge that appears on the proposal summary screen, just above the 'Submit Proposal' button. It contains two pieces of dynamically-generated social proof: (1) a host satisfaction metric ('Guests who stayed with Sarah rated their experience 4.9/5') and (2) a commitment-specific reassurance ('97% of guests who proposed to this host had their proposal accepted'). The badge is subtle ‚Äî it doesn't scream ‚Äî but its placement at the peak uncertainty moment leverages Cialdini's finding that social proof is most influential during uncertainty.

visual_spec.layout: Flexbox row ‚Äî icon on the left, two-line text stack on the right, all contained in a compact pill-shaped container
visual_spec.background: rgba(140, 104, 238, 0.06) ‚Äî a barely-there purple tint that signals reassurance without overwhelming

typography.heading: Inter, 13px (--text-sm-md), 600 weight, var(--primary-purple) #31135D for the stat
typography.body: DM Sans, 12px (--text-sm), 400 weight, var(--text-gray) #6b7280 for the label
typography.accent: Inter, 12px (--text-sm), 600 weight, var(--secondary-purple) rgb(109,49,194) for the percentage

spacing.gap: var(--gap-md) 0.75rem between icon and text, 2px between text lines

visual_spec.color_usage: Accent purple at very low opacity (6%) for the background ‚Äî enough to create a distinct zone but not enough to feel like a marketing callout. Secondary purple for the key stat numbers. Primary purple for the host name reference. Everything is restrained ‚Äî this badge succeeds by being trustworthy, not loud.

interaction_spec.default_state: Badge is visible but unobtrusive, positioned between the proposal summary and the submit button. The stat numbers are visible immediately.
interaction_spec.hover: Subtle border color intensifies to rgba(140, 104, 238, 0.3) and background to 0.1 opacity. A tooltip could show the sample size ('Based on 23 past guests').
interaction_spec.click: Tapping expands to show a mini detail card with the host's review breakdown: overall rating, response rate, and a single highlighted review quote from a similar guest. Tapping again collapses.
interaction_spec.animation: Badge fades in (0.3s ease) with a subtle slide-up from 4px when the proposal summary screen loads. No flashy animations ‚Äî the design language says 'reliable information' not 'attention grab.'
interaction_spec.responsive: Badge takes full width on mobile, maintaining the same compact height. Text stays on two lines. The expandable detail is a bottom sheet on mobile.

copy_spec.primary_text: Guests rate stays with Sarah 4.9 out of 5
copy_spec.secondary_text: 97% of proposals to this host are accepted
micro_copy: Guests like you loved this host
do: Use the host's first name to maintain the relationship frame
Show honest numbers ‚Äî if only 5 guests have stayed, say 'Based on 5 past guests'
Place the badge within the natural visual flow ‚Äî between summary and submit, not as a sidebar or popup
dont: Never fabricate or round up stats ‚Äî authenticity is the entire point
Never use exclamation marks or urgency language ‚Äî this is reassurance, not marketing
Never show this badge if the host has fewer than 3 reviews ‚Äî minimum sample for credible proof

before_after.after: Split Lease proposal screen: Between your proposal summary and the submit button, a quiet badge tells you 'Guests rate stays with Sarah 4.9/5 ‚Äî 97% of proposals accepted.' At the moment you're most nervous, the platform gives you exactly the reassurance you need.
